  • Tracheal suctioning has become obsolete and is no longer routinely performed unless specifically indicated.
  • Suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided as it can stimulate the vagal nerve, leading to apnea and/or bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nose-mouth: This is incorrect as suctioning the nose first increases the risk of aspiration.

 

Option C. Mouth-nose-oesophagus: Suctioning the esophagus is not part of the standard procedure and can cause complications such as vagal stimulation.

 

Option D. Trachea-nose-mouth: Tracheal suctioning is obsolete and not recommended in modern neonatal resuscitation protocols.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Ebstein anomaly
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot
  3. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  4. Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC) are both cyanotic congenital heart diseases that cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

3. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): In TGA, the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched, which results in deoxygenated blood being circulated throughout the body. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood occurs, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow because the deoxygenated blood is directed to the lungs.

 

4. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC): In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect to the right atrium or systemic veins, causing a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. This also leads to increased blood flow to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 4: Ebstein anomaly does not cause increased pulmonary blood flow. Ebstein anomaly involves downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Both Ebstein anomaly and Tetralogy of Fallot cause decreased pulmonary blood flow. Tetralogy of Fallot includes pulmonary stenosis, which limits blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Tetralogy of Fallot causes decreased pulmonary blood flow due to the presence of pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases such as Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC) cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet
Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of administering free-flow oxygen in a neonate?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

 

Free-flow oxygen refers to the administration of oxygen without the need for positive pressure ventilation. It is typically used to provide supplemental oxygen to neonates who are breathing spontaneously.

 

  • Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow freely into the mask and can provide free-flow oxygen.
  • Face mask: Using a face mask can administer free-flow oxygen effectively.
  • Tubing near mouth and nose: Placing oxygen tubing near the mouth and nose is a common method to deliver free-flow oxygen.

 

However, bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet does not provide a means for oxygen to flow freely. This method relies on positive pressure ventilation, where the bag is squeezed to push air (and oxygen if connected) into the neonate's lungs, not allowing for the passive flow of oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow through the inlet, providing free-flow oxygen.

 

Option B. Face mask: A face mask can be used to deliver free-flow oxygen effectively.

 

Option C. Tubing near mouth and nose: This is a standard method for administering free-flow oxygen to neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free-flow oxygen can be administered using methods that allow passive flow of oxygen, such as a face mask or tubing near the mouth and nose. Bag and mask ventilation without an oxygen inlet does not allow for free-flow oxygen administration.

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

 

Surgical correction of a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) primarily helps in relieving the symptoms of congestive heart failure, which often manifest as failure to thrive in infants. Infants with VSD may experience poor weight gain, difficulty feeding, excessive sweating, irritability, and signs of respiratory distress such as tachypnea and labored breathing. These symptoms arise because the left-to-right shunt created by the VSD increases pulmonary blood flow, leading to pulmonary overcirculation and congestive heart failure. Surgical intervention closes the defect, thereby normalizing blood flow and alleviating the symptoms of heart failure, allowing the infant to grow and thrive normally.

 

The key indications for VSD surgery include:

 

  • Large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension.
  • Qp ratio greater than 2:1 (indicating a significant left-to-right shunt).
  • Supracristal VSD, which carries a risk of aortic valve involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is not typically associated with VSD. VSD primarily affects the heart and pulmonary circulation rather than directly causing changes in the acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias in infants are usually related to electrolyte imbalances or other cardiac conditions, but not directly to VSD. Surgical correction of VSD is aimed at correcting the structural defect, not managing arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Heart block: Heart block is a conduction issue in the heart and is not a feature directly caused by VSD. VSD surgery does not specifically address heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.
